TopicTitle: Nexo launch is planned for tomorrow (23 july 2016)

Articles.Content:
yes, I know "Nexo" is not the right way to write it, but my keyboard doesn't support the correct letter to write it properly. >:(

 

Tomorrow, Copenhagen Suborbial will launch their test rocket at 12:00 CEST(unless they have delays, of course).

They expect to arrive in the launch area at 10:00 CEST; You can Watch the launch live here, the livestream will begin at 10:CEST.
Best of luck to CS guys

CopSub have set up a livestream, it's scheduled to start in about ten minutes.

If you go to youtube, CopSub are currently giving info in the chat. At least two hours to the actual launch.

Edited July 23, 2016 by Kryten
Seem like a ship is holding up the launch by entering the area. I saw Kryten post edited 4 hours ago and the rocket is still at go/no go stage.

Countdown is GO! Good luck!

 

OH NO! Mission loss couple of seconds after launch

Edited July 23, 2016 by Scotius

Ouch.

They aren't going to space today. Great launch though.

Edited July 23, 2016 by RainDreamer
It looked like an engine failure. There was a huge plume of fire\smoke, then rocket lost the thrust and fell back.
I thought it was a tank burst, seeing a lot of LOX boil off during recovery.
Rocket appears to be intact and is being recovered.
People blame a Sweedish Viking Pirate Hacker Boat for the failure. XD

Edited July 23, 2016 by Magion
Now I'm really curious as to what went wrong. They had plenty of successful engine tests, I doubt it had something to do with it. But maybe a seal burt under heavy vibration or something.

The auto sequence runs off of a timer. It is set to open after the full flight duration and a good portion of the fall back down. But before that time came, the rocket had already kissed the ocean.

Edited July 23, 2016 by Streetwind
The thing about Copenhagen Suborbitals is that everyone can walk into the door and say "Hey, you're missing this thing, and I can provide". Do you volunteer?

Preliminary thoughts on the failure, pending full investigation:

Too much LOX loaded during fueling --> too little room for gas remaining in the tank --> too low LOX feed pressure --> engine combustion weak and unstable, and eventually flamed out.

(The Nexo rocket uses a load cell to determine the amount of loaded propellant. Basically, the rocket's weight is monitored during the fueling, and the difference between empty weight and current weight is calculated as the amount of fuel loaded. Anyone following their Youtube channel will recall that they've had issues with this in the past, particularly with the load cell being imprecise... go figure. The ocean waves probably didn't help to make the measurement more reliable.)

The parachute didn't deploy because it was hooked up to a sensor for engine chamber pressure, designed to start a timer after flameout. However, because the chamber pressure was too low right from the start, the flight computer declared the sensor as faulty and substituted a pre-saved value, in order to prevent the parachute from deploying during ascent. Basically, a safeguard designed to prevent a certain problem turned around to bite them in the butt.

(Source)

TL;DR: rocketry is hard

Edited July 25, 2016 by Streetwind
